I am a huge fan of nature documentaries and have been reading, watching, looking up out of curiosity and learning about all sorts of ecological and animal related interesting bits since I was a kid - it's now rare that I come across an educational nature piece that tells me something I had not already seen or heard or read. I just watched maybe 5 of your videos and learned something new and fascinating in each of them! The backwards facing barbs on porcupine quills and how it is being investigated to be replicated in surgical equipment? The fact that the wax on the quill is not only stinky but also antibacterial? The internal structure of a rattlesnake's rattle! We've vaccinated wild frogs! Bugs are evolving to fight back against bats! Amazing. I'm having a blast. Thank you for putting all of this information I have ACTUALLY not seen before up here, it is awesome! :D

Adaptation and evolution

So they're kind of doing the same thing we are with stealth planes and enemy countries, only in the insect world. By the way, adaptation/overcoming is different from "evolution". It is still the same creature and more or less does the same thing, it has only adapted its abilities and techniques. The creature itself has not "evolved" into anything.

This is sooo freaking cool cause it shows a law of nature using a different sense...warnings signs for predators.

Since most larger diurnal predators rely on sight and smell, their poisonous prey evolved bright coloration and toxic fluids to warn predators to stay away.

But with bats, they needed to figure something else out since they were dealing with sound.

What's ironic is the fact that now, this bat is hunting something venomous! (Not poisonous)
Also bat's are not blind, they simply rely on sound when hunting

I can't stop watching these videos. Every story is enthralling. Nature is like a giant chess game with constantly evolving strategies in every sector of the playing field, each player fighting to carve out its place in the game, its own ecological niche. So fascinating. Especially when the stakes are mating, eating, and death. I'm glad to be a human but dang there's a lot to learn from the strategies employed by some of these players, especially the microscopic ones. They have some pretty nasty tricks up their sleeves!

Mid-Holocene, circa 2000: The arms race between bat and moth rages on, and some bats can't keep up with their innovative prey. Some of these bats take to the ground, using their sensitive ears to pick out terrestrial scorpions and crickets. The bats soon evolve resistance to scorpion venom.

Mid-Holocene, circa 3000: Some scorpions counter-evolve with new toxins in their venom, putting off the bats. It won't be long until the bats become resistant to this venom, too.

Late Holocene, circa 5000: Having survived the human-induced peak in global temperatures, the bats are now larger and less membranous. They stop catching prey with their legs, instead using their strengthened jaws.

Late Holocene, circa 50000: The walking bats can no longer breed with their closest relatives. Their heavy bones pin them to the ground, though they can fly awkwardly for a small distance.

Early Neocene, 2 million years from now: Weighing in at 3 kilograms, these large bats are now flightless. Their size allows them to take new prey which has not counter-adapted to them yet, such as mice and small snakes.

Mid-Neocene, 5 million years from now: Underneath a swarm of its long-lost relatives, a large beast ambles out of its den, pricking up its large ears to the new night's wind. It hears a scrambling prey item, which in only a few moment's time is the animal's dinner. But what's this -- the prey is not a cricket or a scorpion, or even a mouse or rat, but a descendant of the wild turkey! The colossal 20-kilogram creature, no longer a "bat" in any sense of the word, drags its prize into its den to finish later. A new top predator has evolved on planet Earth.

Deep Look, I have a question that I can't find anywhere on the internet or in books, or anywhere really. How can I hear a bat's echolocation when so many scientists say it is beyond the range of human hearing? No one else I know can, and I have proven that I can because when out I will say, "I hear bats" and then we will all see them fly overhead.
Also, I have to say, the people on forums who claim to be able to hear do not describe it the way I hear it, so they might not be hearing actual sonar.
They describe it more as a squeak whereas I describe it more as a series of repeating, high pitched, waves that pulsate. Maybe not the best description, but it's difficult to describe really...

Not a skeptic by any means, but I've always wondered how, say, an insect can be disgusting to EAT or even poisonous; if that trait only benefits the species as a whole, and not the individual organisms that actually pass on those genes.
What I mean is that being poisonous, only comes in handy when you're being eaten. But IF you're being eaten, you won't get to pass on those poison genes and your children won't be poisonous as well. So how do they evolve like that??

I could easily hear the echolocation sound they make when I was a kid, and it sounded a lot like the sound effect you played, only much higher.  I can still hear it a little, but it's extremely faint.  It sounds like super-rapid electronic beeps at a super-high frequency.  No one else I was with could ever hear it though.  I've always been extremely sensitive to high pitched sounds, and I was actually found to be able to hear tones higher than anyone else in my elementary school class when we did a group experiment with sound technicians, many years ago.  The downside to this sensitivity is that, whenever a siren goes by me on the street, I have to forcefully plug my ears because it feels like something is stabbing into my eardrum..
